scenario:
📧 Email from: noreply@paypal-security.com

⚠️ URGENT: Account Suspended

Your PayPal account has been temporarily suspended due to unusual activity. Click here to verify your identity within 24 hours or your account will be permanently closed.

[Verify Account Now] → bit.ly/pp-verify-2024
explanation: 🚨 Red flags: Suspicious sender domain, urgent language, shortened URL, and requesting immediate action. PayPal uses official domains and never threatens permanent closure via email.

scenario:
💬 WhatsApp Message from +1-555-0123:

"Hey! I found this amazing crypto investment opportunity. My friend made $50K in just 2 weeks! 🚀💰 You just need to send 0.1 BTC to get started. Want the link?"
explanation: 🚨 Classic crypto scam: Unsolicited investment advice, unrealistic returns, upfront payment required, and pressure from 'friends' who made money.

scenario:
🐦 Twitter/X Post from @ElonMusk_Official (Verified ✓):

"To celebrate Tesla's success, I'm giving away 10,000 BTC! Send 0.5-2 BTC to the address below and I'll send back 5-20 BTC immediately! Only first 1000 people! 🎉

bc1qxy2kgdygjrsqtzq2n0yrf2493p83kkfjhx0wlh"
explanation: 🚨 Fake giveaway scam: Even with a verified checkmark, this is fraudulent. Real celebrities never ask you to send crypto first. The account is impersonating Elon Musk.

scenario:
📱 SMS from Bank of America (555-0199):

"BOA ALERT: Suspicious $2,847 transaction detected on your account. If this wasn't you, reply STOP or call 1-800-432-1000 immediately to secure your account."
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Banks do send fraud alerts via SMS. The number matches BOA's official fraud line, and they're not asking for personal info - just to call their official number.

scenario:
💻 Pop-up on website:

"🎉 CONGRATULATIONS! 🎉
You're our 1,000,000th visitor today!
You've won a FREE iPhone 15 Pro!
Claim your prize now - Limited time offer!

[CLAIM NOW] [Close]"
explanation: 🚨 Classic fake prize scam: No website tracks visitor numbers like this. These pop-ups lead to data harvesting or payment requests for 'shipping fees.'

scenario:
📧 Email from: support@netflix.com

Subject: Payment Failed - Update Required

Hi [Your Name],

Your Netflix subscription payment couldn't be processed. Please update your payment method within 3 days to avoid service interruption.

[Update Payment Method]

Thanks,
The Netflix Team
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Netflix domain, professional tone, reasonable timeframe, and directing to official account management. Netflix does send payment failure notifications.

scenario:
📱 Instagram DM from @crypto_millionaire_2024:

"I see you're interested in crypto! 👀 I made $100K last month with my exclusive trading signals. Join my VIP group for just $299 and I'll share my secret strategy! Limited spots available! 💎🚀"
explanation: 🚨 Investment scam: Unsolicited DMs, unrealistic profit claims, 'secret strategies,' upfront fees, and artificial scarcity. Legitimate traders don't cold-message strangers.

scenario:
📧 Email from: security@apple.com

Subject: Sign-in attempt from new device

Someone tried to sign in to your Apple ID from a Windows PC in California. If this was you, you can ignore this email.

If this wasn't you, secure your account:
[Secure Account] → appleid.apple.com
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Apple domain, informative (not urgent) tone, links to official Apple ID website, and provides option to ignore if it was you.

scenario:
💬 WhatsApp from unknown number:

"Hi mom! 📱 My phone broke and I'm using a friend's phone. I need $500 urgently for car repairs. Can you send it to this account? I'll pay you back tomorrow! Love you ❤️"

Account: Zelle - sarah.johnson.temp@gmail.com
explanation: 🚨 Family emergency scam: Impersonating family member, creating urgency, asking for money to unfamiliar account. Always verify through another communication method.

scenario:
📧 Email from: no-reply@amazon.com

Your order #123-4567890-1234567 has shipped!

Estimated delivery: Tomorrow by 8 PM
Tracking: [Track Package]

Order total: $89.99
Shipping address: [Your Address]

Questions? Visit Your Orders in Your Account.
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Amazon domain, specific order details, realistic delivery timeframe, and directs to official account page rather than external links.

scenario:
📱 Text from 555-0156:

"FINAL NOTICE: Your car warranty is about to expire! You could be stuck with thousands in repair costs. Press 1 to speak with a specialist about extending your warranty today!"
explanation: 🚨 Extended warranty scam: Unsolicited contact, false urgency, fear tactics, and requesting immediate action. Legitimate warranty companies don't use these tactics.

scenario:
💻 Website: microsoft-support-center.net

"⚠️ CRITICAL SECURITY ALERT ⚠️
Your Windows computer is infected with 5 viruses!
Call Microsoft Support immediately: 1-800-VIRUS-FIX
Do not shut down your computer!"
explanation: 🚨 Tech support scam: Fake Microsoft domain, fear tactics, fake virus warnings, and requesting immediate phone contact. Microsoft doesn't provide support this way.

scenario:
📧 Email from: billing@spotify.com

Subject: Spotify Premium - Payment Confirmation

Thank you for your Spotify Premium subscription!

Plan: Spotify Premium Individual
Amount: $10.99
Next billing date: March 15, 2024

[Manage Subscription] → spotify.com/account
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Spotify domain, standard pricing, reasonable billing cycle, and links to official Spotify account management page.

scenario:
🐦 Twitter/X DM from @support_twitter:

"Your account has been flagged for suspicious activity. To avoid suspension, please verify your identity by providing your username, password, and phone number within 2 hours."
explanation: 🚨 Account takeover scam: Fake support account, requesting login credentials, artificial urgency. Real Twitter support never asks for passwords via DM.

scenario:
📧 Email from: noreply@chase.com

Subject: Monthly Statement Available

Your Chase credit card statement for February 2024 is now available.

Statement balance: $1,247.83
Minimum payment due: $37.00
Due date: March 22, 2024

[View Statement] → chase.com/statements
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Chase domain, standard statement information, reasonable amounts, and links to official Chase website for statement viewing.

scenario:
💬 Facebook Messenger from 'Mark Zuckerberg':

"Congratulations! You've been selected for our Facebook Lottery Program! You've won $750,000! To claim your prize, please send $500 for processing fees to our agent via Western Union."
explanation: 🚨 Fake lottery scam: Impersonating CEO, unsolicited prize notification, requesting upfront fees. Facebook doesn't run lotteries, and prizes never require fees.

scenario:
📱 SMS from 555-0187:

"Your package delivery failed. Reschedule delivery and pay $3.95 shipping fee: usps-redelivery.com/track/AB123456789"

Link leads to: usps-redelivery.com
explanation: 🚨 Fake delivery scam: Suspicious domain (not usps.com), requesting payment for redelivery, and USPS doesn't charge redelivery fees via text links.

scenario:
📧 Email from: security@paypal.com

Subject: New device signed in to your account

A new device signed in to your PayPal account:

Device: iPhone 14
Location: New York, NY
Time: Today at 2:47 PM

If this wasn't you: [Secure Account]
If this was you: No action needed
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official PayPal domain, informative notification, specific details, and provides option to ignore if it was you. PayPal sends these security notifications.

scenario:
💻 Pop-up while browsing:

"⚠️ YOUR COMPUTER IS INFECTED! ⚠️
Windows Defender has detected 3 threats!
Call Windows Support NOW: 1-888-HELP-WIN
Do not close this window or your files will be deleted!"
explanation: 🚨 Tech support scam: Fake virus warnings, fear tactics, impersonating Windows Defender, and requesting immediate phone contact. Real antivirus doesn't work this way.

scenario:
📧 Email from: orders@bestbuy.com

Subject: Order Confirmation - Thank you for your purchase!

Order #: BBY01-123456789
Item: MacBook Pro 16" M3
Price: $2,499.00
Store pickup: Best Buy - Downtown
Ready for pickup: Tomorrow after 2 PM

[View Order Details]
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Best Buy domain, realistic product and pricing, specific order number, reasonable pickup timeframe, and standard order confirmation format.

scenario:
📱 WhatsApp from +44-7911-123456:

"Hello! I'm Sarah from the UK. I found your number online and I have a business proposal. I need someone in your country to receive $2.5 million inheritance money. You'll get 30% commission. Interested?"
explanation: 🚨 Advance fee scam: Unsolicited contact, inheritance money story, too-good-to-be-true commission, and requesting help from strangers. Classic 419 scam pattern.

scenario:
📧 Email from: noreply@uber.com

Subject: Trip Receipt - Thank you for riding with Uber

Trip on March 10, 2024
From: 123 Main St
To: Downtown Mall
Fare: $12.45
Driver: Michael (4.9 ⭐)

[Rate your trip] [Get receipt]
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Uber domain, realistic trip details and pricing, standard receipt format, and typical post-ride communication from Uber.

scenario:
💬 Instagram DM from @investment_guru_official:

"I noticed you follow finance accounts! 📈 I'm giving away my $2000 trading course for FREE to the first 50 people! Just pay $49 shipping for the physical materials. Link in bio! 🎁"
explanation: 🚨 Fake giveaway scam: 'Free' course with shipping fees, artificial scarcity, and targeting based on interests. Digital courses don't need physical shipping.

scenario:
📧 Email from: support@dropbox.com

Subject: Storage almost full

Your Dropbox is 98% full (1.96 GB of 2 GB used).

Upgrade to Dropbox Plus for 2TB of storage:
• 2TB of space
• 30-day file recovery
• Priority support

[Upgrade Now] → dropbox.com/upgrade
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Dropbox domain, realistic storage usage, standard upgrade offer with real features, and links to official Dropbox upgrade page.

scenario:
📱 Text from 555-0198:

"IRS NOTICE: You owe $3,247 in back taxes. Warrant issued for your arrest. Call 1-800-IRS-HELP immediately to avoid jail time. Case #: IRS-2024-7891"
explanation: 🚨 IRS impersonation scam: IRS doesn't contact via text, doesn't threaten arrest, and doesn't demand immediate payment. Always contact IRS directly through official channels.

scenario:
📧 Email from: team@slack.com

Subject: You've been added to StockVerse workspace

You've been invited to join the StockVerse team workspace on Slack.

Workspace: StockVerse
Invited by: john.doe@stockverse.com

[Join Workspace] [Decline Invitation]

Links lead to: slack.com/join/workspace
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Slack domain, realistic workspace invitation, professional format, and links to official Slack join page. Standard team invitation.

scenario:
💻 Website pop-up on news site:

"🎯 You've been selected for our exclusive survey! Answer 3 quick questions about your shopping habits and receive a $100 Amazon gift card! Survey expires in 5 minutes!"

[Start Survey] [Maybe Later]
explanation: 🚨 Survey scam: Fake selection, unrealistic reward for simple survey, artificial time pressure, and designed to collect personal information for identity theft.

scenario:
📧 Email from: billing@adobe.com

Subject: Adobe Creative Cloud - Subscription Renewal

Your Adobe Creative Cloud subscription will renew on March 20, 2024.

Plan: Creative Cloud All Apps
Amount: $52.99/month
Payment method: •••• 4567

[Manage subscription] → adobe.com/account
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Adobe domain, standard pricing, realistic renewal notice, partial card number display, and links to official Adobe account page.

scenario:
📱 WhatsApp from +1-555-0199:

"Hi! This is Jessica from Amazon customer service. We noticed unusual activity on your account. Someone tried to order a $1,200 iPhone. Please confirm your account details to secure it: Username, password, and last 4 digits of your card."
explanation: 🚨 Impersonation scam: Amazon doesn't contact via WhatsApp, requesting login credentials, and creating false urgency. Always contact Amazon through official channels.

scenario:
📧 Email from: no-reply@github.com

Subject: New sign-in from Chrome on Windows

Someone just signed in to your GitHub account:

Browser: Chrome 122
OS: Windows 11
Location: San Francisco, CA
Time: March 10, 2024 at 3:22 PM PST

[This was me] [This wasn't me]
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official GitHub domain, detailed sign-in information, realistic browser/OS details, and provides clear options to confirm or deny the sign-in.

scenario:
💬 Telegram message from @crypto_signals_vip:

"🚨 URGENT SIGNAL 🚨
Buy DOGE now! Elon Musk will announce Tesla accepts Dogecoin in 2 hours! 🚀 This will pump 1000%! Send 1 ETH to our wallet for VIP access to more signals!"

Wallet: 0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b8D4C0532925a3b8D4
explanation: 🚨 Pump and dump scam: False insider information, unrealistic returns, requesting crypto payment, and using celebrity names to create urgency and credibility.

scenario:
📧 Email from: noreply@linkedin.com

Subject: You have 3 new messages

Hi [Your Name],

You have 3 new messages waiting in your LinkedIn inbox.

From: Sarah Johnson, Marketing Director
From: Tech Recruiter at Google
From: Investment Opportunity

[View Messages] → linkedin.com/messaging
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official LinkedIn domain, realistic message notifications, professional sender titles, and links to official LinkedIn messaging page.

scenario:
📱 SMS from 555-0201:

"CONGRATULATIONS! 🎉 You've won $50,000 in the Walmart Customer Appreciation Lottery! Claim your prize by calling 1-800-WIN-CASH and providing confirmation code: WM2024-7891. Expires in 24 hours!"
explanation: 🚨 Fake lottery scam: Walmart doesn't run lotteries, unsolicited prize notification, artificial urgency, and requesting phone contact. Legitimate prizes don't expire in 24 hours.

scenario:
📧 Email from: security@microsoft.com

Subject: Unusual sign-in activity

We detected an unusual sign-in to your Microsoft account:

Account: your.email@gmail.com
Location: Moscow, Russia
Device: Unknown device
Time: Today at 11:47 PM

If this was you, no action needed.
If not: [Secure your account] → account.microsoft.com/security
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Microsoft domain, security notification format, specific details, provides option to ignore, and links to official Microsoft security page.

scenario:
💻 Browser notification:

"🔒 Your browser is out of date and vulnerable to attacks! Update now to protect your personal information. Click here to download the latest security update."

[Update Browser] [Remind me later]

Link leads to: browser-security-update.net
explanation: 🚨 Fake update scam: Suspicious domain (not official browser site), fear tactics about security, and browsers update automatically or through official channels.

scenario:
📧 Email from: orders@target.com

Subject: Your Target order is ready for pickup!

Order #: 123-45-6789
Items: Household essentials (5 items)
Total: $67.43
Store: Target - Westfield Mall
Ready for pickup: Now

[Pickup details] → target.com/orders
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Target domain, realistic order details, standard pickup notification format, and links to official Target orders page.

scenario:
📱 WhatsApp from +234-803-123-4567:

"Greetings! I am Prince Adebayo from Nigeria. I have $15 million trapped in a bank account. I need your help to transfer it to your country. You will receive 25% ($3.75 million) for your assistance. Are you interested?"
explanation: 🚨 Classic Nigerian prince scam: Unsolicited contact, inheritance/trapped money story, too-good-to-be-true commission, and requesting help from strangers.

scenario:
📧 Email from: noreply@zoom.us

Subject: Meeting reminder: Team Standup

You have a meeting starting in 15 minutes:

Topic: Daily Team Standup
Time: March 11, 2024 at 9:00 AM PST
Meeting ID: 123-456-7890
Host: Sarah Johnson

[Join Meeting] → zoom.us/j/1234567890
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Zoom domain, realistic meeting details, standard reminder format, and links to official Zoom meeting join page.

scenario:
💬 Discord DM from @CryptoMaster2024:

"Hey! I saw your message in the crypto channel. I have insider info about a new coin launching tomorrow. It's going to 100x! Send me 0.5 ETH and I'll add you to the private presale. Only 24 hours left!"
explanation: 🚨 Crypto investment scam: Unsolicited DM, insider information claims, unrealistic returns, requesting crypto payment, and artificial urgency. Legitimate investments don't work this way.

scenario:
📧 Email from: support@steam.com

Subject: Steam Guard - New device authorization

A new device is trying to access your Steam account:

Device: Windows PC
Location: Your City, Your State
Time: March 11, 2024 at 7:23 PM

If this is you, enter this code: 7G4H9
If not, change your password: [Secure Account] → store.steampowered.com/account
explanation: ✅ Legitimate: Official Steam domain, Steam Guard security feature, realistic authorization process, provides security code, and links to official Steam account page.
